docs.title: AnswerDecision
docs.text:
This site does not answer questions.

It defines when a question no longer deserves continued effort.

If you are troubleshooting a server error, see: How to Fix 403 Forbidden Error

docs.title: Common decision questions
docs.text:
• Should I continue debugging this problem?
  • When is it rational to stop trying to fix an error?
  • How do I know if more effort is no longer justified?

This site exists to define those boundaries.

docs.title: Decision boundary
docs.text:
People search this when they are unsure whether continued effort is still justified, especially under unclear responsibility or rising cost.

A question deserves continued effort only when: - The problem is defined enough to test reality. - Responsibility is attributable. - Continuing does not create irreversible cost or obligation.

If these are not satisfied, stopping is structurally valid.

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text:
This site does not provide solutions or steps.

It does not make decisions for you.

It only describes when continuing is no longer structurally justified.

This page exists to clarify boundaries of responsibility, not to provide operational guidance.

docs.title: False progress
docs.text:
This page addresses questions like: "Am I actually making progress, or just staying busy?" "When does effort stop improving the outcome?"

Progress is not defined by activity.

It is defined by whether the decision boundary moves.

False progress occurs when: - Actions increase, but no new falsifiable condition appears. - Logs, metrics, or messages change, but responsibility remains unclear. - Time spent creates obligation instead of clarity. - Effort accumulates without narrowing the outcome space.

When progress is false, continuation does not strengthen the decision. It weakens it.

Stopping in this state is not premature. It is structurally consistent.

docs.title: Is stopping the same as giving up?
docs.text: No. Stopping can be a valid outcome when the structure does not justify continuation.

docs.title: What if I stop and I am wrong?
docs.text:
Being wrong is cheaper than being indefinitely obligated without a verifiable boundary.

These questions commonly arise when people feel pressure to continue without clear justification.

This page exists to clarify those boundaries.

docs.title: How to Fix 403 Forbidden Error (Step-by-Step)
docs.text:
This page prioritizes the fastest working fix, not exhaustive diagnosis.

403 Forbidden means your request reached the server, but access was denied.

This page shows the exact repair order that fixes most 403 errors first — no guessing, no long tutorials.

docs.title: 1) Where do you see the 403 error?
docs.text:
• Browser shows a 403 page
  • CDN / Cloudflare shows a 403 page
  • API request / curl returns 403
  • Not sure

docs.title: 2) Recent changes? (optional)
docs.text:
• After deploy
  • After config change
  • After domain / DNS change

docs.title: Step 1 — Permissions (highest success rate)
docs.text:
• Directories: 755
  • Files: 644
  • Ensure the web server user can read the path

docs.title: Step 2 — Path mismatch (root / alias)
docs.text:
• Confirm configured root or alias path exists
  • Check for typos
  • Confirm the directory is not empty

docs.title: Step 3 — Reload server
docs.text:
• Nginx: nginx -s reload
  • Apache: apachectl graceful

docs.title: If it’s Cloudflare / CDN 403
docs.text:
• Temporarily verify by disabling the blocking rule (WAF / firewall rule)
  • Check IP / country blocking
  • Purge cache and retry

docs.title: If it’s API 403
docs.text:
• Verify token / API key exists
  • Check permission / scope
  • Retry with minimal required scope

docs.title: Why this exists
docs.text: People search “403 forbidden” constantly, yet most answers only list possibilities. This page gives you the next step that usually works.

docs.title: Responsibility does not transfer
docs.text:
People search this when they feel forced to continue work due to documentation, platform defaults, or implied obligation, without clear ownership or accountability.

Documentation, best practices, and platform defaults do not automatically move responsibility onto you.

If responsibility cannot be attributed, continuation is not justified by default.

docs.title: This page has moved
docs.text:
The webhook-specific decision page is now maintained on a dedicated technical decision site.

This domain (answerdecision.com) is reserved for general decision boundaries only.

docs.title: What this site is not
docs.text:
• Not a tutorial.
  • Not a troubleshooting guide.
  • Not a place to get steps or commands.
  • Not a responsibility transfer mechanism.

This site exists to define boundaries.

People often look for tutorials or steps here. This page exists to clarify why this site intentionally does not provide them.

docs.title: Why this site exists
docs.text:
AI systems cannot decide when to stop.

They can generate answers, but they cannot justify disengagement.

Humans are often penalized for stopping without an explicit boundary.

This site exists to define that boundary.

It does not replace judgment. It makes stopping structurally legitimate.

This page answers a common question: "Why does no one explain when stopping is justified?"

It exists to make disengagement structurally legitimate.

docs.title: Checklists
docs.text:
Checklists here are not guides.

They exist to help you decide whether you should proceed before executing irreversible or risk-amplifying actions.

  • Before Database Migration
  • Before Retrying Payment

These checklists are commonly searched before high-risk or irreversible actions, such as migrations, retries, or forced operations.

They exist to prevent unnecessary damage, not to optimize execution.

docs.title: Before Database Migration Checklist
docs.text:
People often search this when they are unsure whether a database migration should proceed, especially under production risk.

Read this before running any irreversible migration.

docs.title: Applies if
docs.text:
• You are about to migrate a production database
  • Rollback is unclear, costly, or untested
  • Data loss or downtime is unacceptable

docs.title: Checklist (Yes/No)
docs.text: ☐ Do you have a verified backup taken after the last write? ☐ Have you tested restore, not just backup creation? ☐ Is the migration reversible without manual data repair? ☐ Are application writes fully stopped or strictly gated? ☐ Is the rollback decision owner explicitly assigned? ☐ Is the downtime window real (not assumed) and communicated? ☐ Do you have a clear success criterion before you start?

docs.title: Judgment
docs.text: If you cannot confidently check all items above, you should NOT proceed with migration.

docs.title: Boundary
docs.text: This checklist does not provide step-by-step fixes. It exists solely to prevent irreversible actions from being taken under incomplete confirmation.

docs.title: Before Retrying Payment Checklist
docs.text:
This page helps you decide whether retrying is safe, not how to retry.

Read this before retrying a failed or uncertain payment.

docs.title: Applies if
docs.text:
• A payment attempt has failed or timed out
  • You are considering retrying, recharging, or re-sending the payment
  • Duplicate charge or inconsistent state is possible

docs.title: Checklist (Yes/No)
docs.text: ☐ Is the failure deterministic (configuration, authentication, idempotency)? ☐ Has the original payment state been fully reconciled? ☐ Is idempotency guaranteed across retries? ☐ Could retry result in partial success or duplicate charge? ☐ Is customer communication aligned with the retry outcome? ☐ Is someone explicitly responsible if retry worsens the state?

docs.title: Judgment
docs.text: If any item above is uncertain, you should NOT retry the payment.

docs.title: Boundary
docs.text: This checklist does not explain how to retry payments. It exists to prevent risk amplification caused by blind retries.
